commit_message:
Update network_data.yaml file in swift for update/upgrade

Currently, we preserve the network_data.yaml file for update
and upgrade. The behavior is correct, because we don't want to
override the network datas with the default one during upgrade
but we hit issues when a new key has been added in the new
network_data.yaml file (like the 'vlan' key).
This result to a not found key and then some Heat templates
values that is not correctly set.

Change-Id: Ia3de48b63e854813778eb112a45ab7d28f54ac32

inline question janki does this do what you need?

WRT making the default be docker.yaml, it sounds like a resonable change to me. But I don't think that will do what you need. If you override the env file (like to add opendaylight), then you would no longer get the default docker.yaml and so you still have to add -e docker.yaml (or i miss something still )

It would have to be more like, 'always add docker.yaml to whatever the user specified' and I don't think *that* is reasonable. wdyt?"}, {'account_id': 20866, 'date': '2017-09-26 10:14:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (2 comments)
 > 
 > inline question janki does this do what you need?
 > 
 > WRT making the default be docker.yaml, it sounds like a resonable
 > change to me. But I don't think that will do what you need. If you
 > override 
Not override. Add ODL along with docker.yaml. Currently, we have to specify both -e docker.yaml -e opendaylight.yaml otherwise only ODL images are created. with this change, you will just need to specify -e opendaylight.yaml to prepare because docker.yaml would already be included.

 > the env file (like to add opendaylight), then you would no
 > longer get the default docker.yaml and so you still have to add -e
 > docker.yaml (or i miss something still )
 > 
 > It would have to be more like, 'always add docker.yaml to whatever
 > the user specified' and I don't think *that* is reasonable. wdyt?
This would be like docker.yaml + whatever user specified. I think this is reasonable because then user will have to specify less env files and hence less confusion. Downside (not sure if it really is a downside) is specifying no env file will produce image reference for services only supported and not all services present in OOO."}, {'account_id': 20866, 'date': '2017-09-26 10:16:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2017-09-26 05:37:05.000000000', 'message': 'Add docker.yaml by default to prepare command

prepare command prepares a list of docker images for services enabled.

openstack overcloud container image prepare --namespace tripleoupstream
--tag latest --env-file ~/docker_registry.yaml -e /usr/share/
triple-common/environments/services-docker/neutron-opendaylight.yaml

produces just ODL related images.

Add docker.yaml as default service-environment-file so that above
command produces images for all supported services + ODL. Adding too
many env files is confusing to users.

Change-Id: Icc0aa777fa41761907d4acbd5974f91db748a65e
Closes-Bug: #1719288
'}]
commit_message:
Add docker.yaml by default to prepare command

prepare command prepares a list of docker images for services enabled.

openstack overcloud container image prepare --namespace tripleoupstream
--tag latest --env-file ~/docker_registry.yaml -e /usr/share/
triple-common/environments/services-docker/neutron-opendaylight.yaml

produces just ODL related images.

Add docker.yaml as default service-environment-file so that above
command produces images for all supported services + ODL. Adding too
many env files is confusing to users.

Change-Id: Icc0aa777fa41761907d4acbd5974f91db748a65e
Closes-Bug: #1719288

commit_message:
Stop installing nodepool in all the test envs

We only need it in the nodepool env. Also, install from pip and let
tox-siblings take care of updating from source for us.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/611629
Change-Id: I0ece7b751662b4198276e88adcf263634fd792d6

http://logs.openstack.org/30/611630/1/check/openstack-zuul-jobs-linters/343fe56/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-10-19_07_04_55_219610 seems to show that no siblings are installed.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-10-19 18:23:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-10-19 18:24:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 2, 'date': '2018-10-19 18:34:30.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-10-19 20:24:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2

It is weird to have a setup.py that mostly works here, but I think this is fine so that we can use existing well tested machinery to test with projects from source.

I do think we want to test Zuul and nodepool from source because that is how infra deploys them. These deployments may want to take advantage of unreleased features that will break if we don't install from source in testing."}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-10-19 20:31:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Update ansible library location to envsitepackagesdir

We install zuul so that we can pick up library entries. The proper path
for this is envsitepackagesdir. Also, just list zuul in the requirements
so that we're not cloning remotely. tox-siblings will take care of it in
the gate for us, because we add zuul to required-projects in the
openstack-zuul-jobs-linters job.

This adds a setup.py and setup.cfg so that tox-siblings can do its
thing.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/611607
Change-Id: I864308af3424a0b0505a252d0d5cf44277172fbf

commit_message:
DVR-HA: Configure extra routes on router namespace in dvr_snat node

Extra routes are not configured on Router namespaces in dvr_snat
node with DVR-HA configuration.
This patch fixes the problem.

Change-Id: If620b23564479042aa6f58640bcd6705e5eb52cf
Closes-Bug: #1797037
(cherry picked from commit 81652cd939ebaf7ea09e5f8dd31d8185619c8243)

commit_message:
Remove deprecated API settings

We moved "bind_host", "bind_port", "auth_strategy", and "api_handler"
into the api_settings section in the configuration file. These settings
have now reached the end of their deprecation cycle and are being removed.

Change-Id: I323a7bdceae5a8d0e3025800beaf1d0a13c12ef8

commit_message:
Use tempest.common.identity.identity_utils for project management

This uses identity_utils from tempest.common.identity for
project creation/deletion in non-identity tests:

    A client that abstracts v2 and v3 identity operations.

    This can be used for creating and tearing down projects in tests.
    It should not be used for testing identity features.

This is a common pattern in Tempest and should be used in Patrole, too.

Change-Id: Id87294bd19c7abd92d202b5ba6b49e4aac6c7e42

commit_message:
SUSE: Add support for openSUSE Leap 15

This also removes python-keystonemiddleware from the distro packages
since anything that needs it should pull it as a dependency.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/604473
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/604286
Change-Id: I8398b70fc7e371d163bed8bed8fc11f50c521e28

Merge the system protocol assignments into the iptables name
to protocol mapping array, IPTABLES_PROTOCOL_NAME_MAP, so that
systems with updated or new values in /etc/protocols can
successfully install iptables rules.

This was done as an IptablesFirewallDriver() instance mapping
since there is typically only a single instance per-agent,
and it also allows us to more easily unit test it.

commit_message:
Use system protocol assigments for iptables protocol map

Merge the system protocol assignments into the iptables name
to protocol mapping array, IPTABLES_PROTOCOL_NAME_MAP, so that
systems with updated or new values in /etc/protocols can
successfully install iptables rules.

This was done as an IptablesFirewallDriver() instance mapping
since there is typically only a single instance per-agent,
and it also allows us to more easily unit test it.

Conflicts:
    neutron/agent/linux/iptables_firewall.py
    neutron/tests/unit/agent/linux/test_iptables_firewall.py

Change-Id: Ib73def4e2a9e3644462fdee312768382fcb800a5
Closes-Bug: #1783378
(cherry picked from commit 034db863a02ce38a520e4b8aa3a65e1ccdb37f30)

'}, {'created': '2017-07-26 12:21:45.000000000', 'message': "Add Response class to return request-id to caller

This change is required to return 'request_id' from client
to log request_id mappings of cross-project requests.

Instantiating class 'keystoneclient.v3.client.Client' using
'include_metadata=True' will cause manager response to return
a new 'Response' class instead of just the data. This 'Response'
class is going to have additional metadata properties available
like 'request_ids' and the original data will be available as
property 'data' to it.

This change is backward compatible since user has to set a new
parameter 'include_metadata=True' to client in order to get the
request_id returned.

Co-author: Dinesh Bhor <dinesh.bhor@nttdata.com>
Partially Implements: blueprint return-request-id-to-caller

commit_message:
Add Response class to return request-id to caller

This change is required to return 'request_id' from client
to log request_id mappings of cross-project requests.

Instantiating class 'keystoneclient.v3.client.Client' using
'include_metadata=True' will cause manager response to return
a new 'Response' class instead of just the data. This 'Response'
class is going to have additional metadata properties available
like 'request_ids' and the original data will be available as
property 'data' to it.

This change is backward compatible since user has to set a new
parameter 'include_metadata=True' to client in order to get the
request_id returned.

Co-author: Dinesh Bhor <dinesh.bhor@nttdata.com>
Partially Implements: blueprint return-request-id-to-caller

(1 comment)

keystoneclient/access.py and keystoneclient/v3/tokens.py are now part of keystoneauth, we shouldn't add new features to them. When keystoneclient makes a request, it uses the same request ID for the token fetch and the action itself, so I think for most cases that should be sufficient. commit_message:
Add return-request-id-to-caller function(v3)

Added return-request-id-to-caller function to resources and resource
managers in the following files.

* keystoneclient/v3/projects.py

The methods in the resource class and resource manager return
a wrapper class that has 'request_ids' property.
The caller can get request ids of the callee via the property.

NOTE:
Remaining resources from the V3 package are already covered in the
base patch: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/329913/

Change-Id: I0133d51cfadc02e2dd926b8b0419b2e1dd0fa92a
Co-authored-by: Ankit Agrawal <ankit11.agrawal@nttdata.com>
Co-authored-by: Dinesh Bhor <dinesh.bhor@nttdata.com>
Implements: blueprint return-request-id-to-caller

commit_message:
releasenotes: oslo-messaging-separate-backends add project name

Without this patch, the release notes published at
https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/openstack-ansible/rocky.html contains
the same line multiple times which is not very clear.

[...]
    Support separate oslo.messaging services for RPC and Notifications
    to enable operation of separate and different messaging backend servers.

    Support separate oslo.messaging services for RPC and Notifications
    to enable operation of separate and different messaging backend servers.
[...]

commit_message:
Only run OpenStack tasks once

By having run_once on the entire include, the set_fact only
runs on a single node which means the configuration for all
the other nodes fails.

This patch makes the play get included for everything, but
only the OpenStack creation happens once, with fact setting
happening on all nodes.

Change-Id: Iddd4afebb491dcf9f78f13b7ad96574f8a68e074
(cherry picked from commit e82141a02ab210484d489b83c70b690e94c67bc1)

[{'created': '2018-10-12 16:06:51.000000000', 'message': "Don't persist RequestSpec.requested_destination

The RequestSpec.requested_destination, similar to the
retry field, is per-request/operation, and persisting
it can caues issues when subsequent move requests.

For example, if you cold migrate a server to a specific
host and then live migrate that server without specifying
a host, the requested target host from the cold migrate
is sent to the scheduler for the live migration, but since
that is where the instance is already running, it's
rejected with NoValidHost.

This is a similar issue to the need to call
RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations() in all move operations
in conductor. However, rather than try to whack this mole in
every place the request spec is sent to the scheduler, like
reset_forced_destinations() is used, we simply don't need to
persist the requested_destination field since it's just a
vehicle to tell the scheduler which host we want.

The related functional regression test is updated to show
the bug is now fixed.

Change-Id: I2a78f0754c63381c57e7e1c610d0938b6df0f537
Closes-Bug: #1797580

commit_message:
Don't persist RequestSpec.requested_destination

The RequestSpec.requested_destination, similar to the
retry field, is per-request/operation, and persisting
it can caues issues when subsequent move requests.

For example, if you cold migrate a server to a specific
host and then live migrate that server without specifying
a host, the requested target host from the cold migrate
is sent to the scheduler for the live migration, but since
that is where the instance is already running, it's
rejected with NoValidHost.

This is a similar issue to the need to call
RequestSpec.reset_forced_destinations() in all move operations
in conductor. However, rather than try to whack this mole in
every place the request spec is sent to the scheduler, like
reset_forced_destinations() is used, we simply don't need to
persist the requested_destination field since it's just a
vehicle to tell the scheduler which host we want.

The related functional regression test is updated to show
the bug is now fixed.

Change-Id: I2a78f0754c63381c57e7e1c610d0938b6df0f537
Closes-Bug: #1797580

commit_message:
Adding UTs for firewall driver_api

FWaaS L3 Driver API [1] has been updated in Rocky by adding
notification callback events without Unit Test.
It might raise some unexpected regression in further.
This patch intends to add UTs for Driver API Neutron-FWaaS.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/578718/

Co-Authored-By: Kim Bao Long <longkb@vn.fujitsu.com>
Change-Id: I7a1ffa1ad6ba370e63a7b87f697ac9f3e9d9b57a

commit_message:
Add functional test for FWaaS L3 logging driver

In Rocky, FWaaS L3 logging driver [1] has been merged without
functional test. It might raise some unexpected regression in further.
So this patch intends to add functional test for FWaaS logging driver.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/553738/

Change-Id: Ia7447cfa89c1464f4214e9930c7f9fd707a978a3

commit_message:
Drop expired connections before retrieving from the queue

If all the connections in the queue have expired, we don't want to
return any of them.  Because we previously dropped connections only
after retrieval, it was possible we would choose and return a dead
connection.  Doing the cleanup first should prevent that.

Change-Id: I650537e7b44d6bdd552def6a3b2de42a60ed9b94
Closes-Bug: 1775341

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-12 15:39:15.000000000', 'message': "Add regression test for bug 1797580

Microversion 2.56 allows cold migrating to a specified target host. The
compute API sets the requested destination on the request spec with the
specified target host and then conductor sends that request spec to the
scheduler to validate the host. Conductor later persists the changes to
the request spec because it's the resize flow and the flavor could change
(even though in this case it won't since it's a cold migrate). After
confirming the resize, if the server is live migrated it will fail during
scheduling because of the persisted RequestSpec.requested_destination
from the cold migration, and you can't live migrate to the same host on
which the instance is currently running.

This change adds a test to recreate the regression bug.

Change-Id: I588655fdd90917d00ccf5eb0a8df7bccc1ac0e81
Related-Bug: #1797580
"}]
commit_message:
Add regression test for bug 1797580

Microversion 2.56 allows cold migrating to a specified target host. The
compute API sets the requested destination on the request spec with the
specified target host and then conductor sends that request spec to the
scheduler to validate the host. Conductor later persists the changes to
the request spec because it's the resize flow and the flavor could change
(even though in this case it won't since it's a cold migrate). After
confirming the resize, if the server is live migrated it will fail during
scheduling because of the persisted RequestSpec.requested_destination
from the cold migration, and you can't live migrate to the same host on
which the instance is currently running.

This change adds a test to recreate the regression bug.

Change-Id: I588655fdd90917d00ccf5eb0a8df7bccc1ac0e81
Related-Bug: #1797580

commit_message:
Extract volume image metadata into volume utils

The "get_volume_image_metadata" method is a common function to
get the volume image metadata, and "enable_bootable_flag" method
is used to enable volume bootable flag.

These are also can be used by re-image interface, this patch
extract them into volume utils.

Change-Id: I37af102c95023f7ad6d23c8aa93d63d8fe6f547d
blueprint: add-volume-re-image-api

subject: Extract _get_image_metadata into volume utils

commit_message:
Extract _get_image_metadata into volume utils

The "_get_image_metadata" method is a common function to check
whether we can use this image to write a volume or not.

These logic also can be used by re-image interface, this patch
extract it into volume utils.

Change-Id: Ie1b9fd8b4f335f0b660984ca1b3121b2f203704d
blueprint: add-volume-re-image-api

commit_message:
api-ref: Add response fields and response example for snapshot manage

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#manage-an-existing-snapshot
Response fields and response example are missing in the
"Manage an existing snapshot" api ref, this is to add them.

Change-Id: I5a3f397e1a4d7e38d35b707f3c164ef7522aea95

Some drivers will report total_capacity and free_capacity

Change-Id: Icd206ba3733adf9543a9e1384ef7245e287ee858

commit_message:
api_ref: total_capacity and free_capacity can be float

Some drivers will report total_capacity and free_capacity
as float, so this is to change the data type description to
include floating point.

Change-Id: Icd206ba3733adf9543a9e1384ef7245e287ee858

[{'created': '2018-10-11 09:13:49.000000000', 'message': 'api-ref: totalSnapshotsUsed in limits response should be integer

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#show-absolute-limits-for-project

totalSnapshotsUsed in limits response should be integer, but
not string. And totalSnapshotsUsed is also used in hosts response

'}]
commit_message:
api-ref: totalSnapshotsUsed in limits response should be integer

https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/block-storage/v3/index.html#show-absolute-limits-for-project

totalSnapshotsUsed in limits response should be integer, but
not string. And totalSnapshotsUsed is also used in hosts response
which is string, so this is to add a new parameter for totalSnapshotsUsed.

Change-Id: I48f61f50defe9782d5a7afb7d7fa245f562785a0

commit_message:
[Functional] Increase test_timeout for db migration tests

In Neutron we hit quite often same issue as Manila, see [1] for
details.
It looks that solution for this problem may be increase timeout
for test_walk_version functional tests.
Higher timeout will be applied for tests for both pgsql and mysql
backends but it is mostly needed for mysql because 'pymysql' works
much slower on slow nodes than 'psycopg2'

This patch adds also new decorator to set individual timeout for
tests.

[1] https://bugs.launchpad.net/manila/+bug/1501272

Change-Id: I5f344af6dc3e5a6ee5f52c250b6c719e1b43e02d
Closes-Bug: #1687027
(cherry picked from commit c2c37272bf788aac63399127cddd487dc0f15c38)

[{'account_id': 29267, 'date': '2018-10-09 14:12:11.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-10-09 14:14:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

You have now submitted three different changes. PLease abandon two - and decide where to continue.

See https://review.openstack.org/#/q/owner:%22Michal+Cila%22+status:open for full list

Please read first http://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html , it explains the git workflow we use.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-10-09 14:16:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Also, check your commit message, see https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html#committing-a-change .

You need a single line as subject, followed by an empty line followed by the body - instead of a single long line you have now.'}, {'account_id': 29267, 'date': '2018-10-09 15:07:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-10-09 18:13:01.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Note that you will start with an empty repository. Your very first
patch needs to setup the repository and add all infrastructure so that
the jobs pass (this can be done with a cookiecutter project).

Also, you can import an existing repository including it's history if
you have one. Once the repository is created, importing is not
possible anymore, changes will have to go through the normal review
process.

If you have a lot of history to import, please use the upstream field
instead of creating a repository and then pushing the patches one at a
time. Pushing a large number of related patches all at one time causes
the CI infrastructure to slow down, which impacts work on all of the
other projects using it. After repo creation the infra team will not
push any content to it; this is your only chance to import directly.


Please:
a) confirm that starting with an empty repo is fine.
b) tell us whether this is part of an official project or just hosted here?"}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-10-19 16:07:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Workflow-1

Michal, I'm waiting for your answer. Setting to WIP to signal that this cannot proceed as is."}, {'account_id': 29267, 'date': '2018-10-19 18:36:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Sorry, I was dealing with some issues and totally forgot about this review. Please close this for now, I will open the request once we have more working code. Thanks'}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-10-19 18:39:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Michal, you can abandon this yourself. You can also start with an empty repo and get code in...'}, {'account_id': 29267, 'date': '2018-10-19 18:40:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Ok, let's merge it, please. We will then push the code in the empty repo :) thanks for your patience!"}, {'account_id': 6547, 'date': '2018-10-19 18:43:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 -Workflow

Ok,you'll have my +2 - and then we need another reviewer..."}, {'account_id': 4146, 'date': '2018-10-19 19:05:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

commit_message:
Add openstack/flare project.

Flare is a service for running and scheduling burstable task resources.
Typical job is unlimited scientific batch from multiple teams with multiple
priorities, which runs on limited compute resources (GPUs for example).

Change-Id: Ic87a7aad09e6b768d7c40d507bff7a163d6bbe3d

Please, note failing MySQL functional job in server-side change [1]:

It is failing due to Trove client dependency lacking options added in this change. In order to merge server-side change we must first merge CLI-side one - correct me if I am wrong. Otherwise server-side tests will not pass.

Same as you, I don't like the ordering of submitting these patches into mainline, however, it is enforced by Trovestack integration suite framework.

Currently, listing instances only allows to get basic information about
entities. To get the details, one need to query instance "show" endpoint

commit_message:
Add detailed list for instances

Currently, listing instances only allows to get basic information about
entities. To get the details, one need to query instance "show" endpoint
for each instance separately. This is inefficient and exposes API to a
heavier load.

There are use cases in which we want to obtain detailed information
about all instances. In particular, in services integrating with Trove.
For example, Vitrage project requires this information to build vertices
and edges in the resource graph for RCA analysis.

This change extends Trove client by optional parameter allowing user  to
specify whether API should include more instance details in the
response.

Change-Id: Iecea2f711a3e23fd63167beb6cab4cecc63bcabe
Signed-off-by: Bartosz Zurkowski <b.zurkowski@samsung.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-21 13:18:29.000000000', 'message': "WIP - Add nova file_backed_memory and memory_backing_dir support for qemu.conf

The libvirt driver now allows utilizing file backed memory for qemu/KVM
virtual machines, via a new configuration attribute
``[libvirt]/file_backed_memory``, defaulting to 0 (disabled).

``[libvirt]/file_backed_memory`` specifies the available capacity in MiB
for file backed memory, at the directory configured for
``memory_backing_dir`` in libvirt's ``qemu.conf``. When enabled, the
libvirt driver will report the configured value for the total memory
capacity of the node, and will report used memory as the sum of all
configured guest memory.

Running Nova with file_backed_memory requires libvirt version 4.0.0 and
qemu version 2.6.0

This introduces parameters QemuMemoryBackingDir and NovaLibvirtFileBackedMemory

Resolves-Bug: 1793687
Depends-On: I0d9eb21fcab01266e501b7fc63c5b2bbb244956a

Change-Id: I47e2f92fb2ed3e66d4bf31814eac9090382ef4e1

commit_message:
Add nova file_backed_memory and memory_backing_dir support for qemu.conf

The libvirt driver now allows utilizing file backed memory for qemu/KVM
virtual machines, via a new configuration attribute
``[libvirt]/file_backed_memory``, defaulting to 0 (disabled).

``[libvirt]/file_backed_memory`` specifies the available capacity in MiB
for file backed memory, at the directory configured for
``memory_backing_dir`` in libvirt's ``qemu.conf``. When enabled, the
libvirt driver will report the configured value for the total memory
capacity of the node, and will report used memory as the sum of all
configured guest memory.

Running Nova with file_backed_memory requires libvirt version 4.0.0 and
qemu version 2.6.0

This introduces parameters QemuMemoryBackingDir and NovaLibvirtFileBackedMemory

Resolves-Bug: 1793687
Depends-On: I0d9eb21fcab01266e501b7fc63c5b2bbb244956a

Change-Id: I47e2f92fb2ed3e66d4bf31814eac9090382ef4e1

commit_message:
Increase size for security hardened images

With the move to containers there has been an increase of
demand on the /var volume. Increase the global size.

Change-Id: Ib806bac815077c2508060719469b5d0f1acc0f99

[{'created': '2018-10-16 06:48:09.000000000', 'message': 'Fix nova-api healthcheck in case of nova metadata wsgi

While we have a dedicated nova_metadata healthcheck script, the
nova_metadata and nova_api use the same container image and the current
nova api healtcheck script still checks the non wsgi implementation. This
changes the nova_api healthcheck script to check the metadata wsgi vhost
config for details instead of the details in nova.conf.

Change-Id: I028caee75e47618d5d0c55054ef33216d05d41b6
Closes-Bug: #1797514
(cherry picked from commit a77d5c86e2a2b5419c42199ac18e2904774ce34d)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix nova-api healthcheck in case of nova metadata wsgi

While we have a dedicated nova_metadata healthcheck script, the
nova_metadata and nova_api use the same container image and the current
nova api healtcheck script still checks the non wsgi implementation. This
changes the nova_api healthcheck script to check the metadata wsgi vhost
config for details instead of the details in nova.conf.

Change-Id: I028caee75e47618d5d0c55054ef33216d05d41b6
Closes-Bug: #1797514
(cherry picked from commit a77d5c86e2a2b5419c42199ac18e2904774ce34d)

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-19 13:58:49.000000000', 'message': 'Avoid ignore_errors on Set ephemeral device by label

Avoids confusing output that looks like:
primary | ERROR: Ignoring Errors

Return code different than zero is normal and should not fail
that task, using failed_when does avoid displaying the task
as a failure when the rc is not zero (most builds).

Change-Id: I00e70c65c73880281f13d8bf92c5779814e57837
'}]
commit_message:
Avoid ignore_errors on Set ephemeral device by label

Avoids confusing output that looks like:
primary | ERROR: Ignoring Errors

Return code different than zero is normal and should not fail
that task, using failed_when does avoid displaying the task
as a failure when the rc is not zero (most builds).

Change-Id: I00e70c65c73880281f13d8bf92c5779814e57837

[{'created': '2018-10-12 21:30:29.000000000', 'message': 'New Airship project - Tempest Plugin

This PS adds a Tempest plugin project for Airship, which will
be used to confirm the correctness of APIs for Airship projects.
This is being created as a standalone project per OpenStack
conventions.

The existing airship-tempest-plugin project to be imported contains
a subset of tests for the Shipyard project; the tests will expand
over time to test other Airship projects as well.

Change-Id: I58d09f41d7f696de628d42cc5504572811d38c61
'}]
commit_message:
New Airship project - Tempest Plugin

This PS adds a Tempest plugin project for Airship, which will
be used to confirm the correctness of APIs for Airship projects.
This is being created as a standalone project per OpenStack
conventions.

The existing airship-tempest-plugin project to be imported contains
a subset of tests for the Shipyard project; the tests will expand
over time to test other Airship projects as well.

Change-Id: I58d09f41d7f696de628d42cc5504572811d38c61

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-29 23:54:25.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I2f1ce3ab401de7068d4ff258092d2f8236dfd09f
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I2f1ce3ab401de7068d4ff258092d2f8236dfd09f
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
Fix the old or invalid doc links

The urls in docs are old or invalid.
Replace them with the right ones for the docs according to
the official OpenStack websites.

Change-Id: Ia264bfb5e9e1a025b0250b139c84c730df05fe9b

[{'created': '2016-01-14 10:21:53.000000000', 'message': "Add return-request-id-to-caller function(v2_0)

Add return-request-id-to-caller function to
resources and resource managers in the following files.

* keystoneclient/v2_0/

The methods in the resource class and resource manager return
a wrapper class that has 'request_ids' property.
The caller can get request ids of the callee via the property.

Change-Id: I849bae3abd50c568d20348d4ea88c10dd6d73f06
Co-authored-by: Ankit Agrawal <ankit11.agrawal@nttdata.com>

commit_message:
Add return-request-id-to-caller function(v2_0)

Add return-request-id-to-caller function to
resources and resource managers in the following files.

* keystoneclient/v2_0/certificates.py
* keystoneclient/v2_0/ec2.py
* keystoneclient/v2_0/endpoints.py
* keystoneclient/v2_0/extensions.py
* keystoneclient/v2_0/roles.py
* keystoneclient/v2_0/services.py
* keystoneclient/v2_0/tenants.py
* keystoneclient/v2_0/tokens.py
* keystoneclient/v2_0/users.py

The methods in the resource class and resource manager return
a wrapper class that has 'request_ids' property.
The caller can get request ids of the callee via the property.

Change-Id: I849bae3abd50c568d20348d4ea88c10dd6d73f06
Co-authored-by: Ankit Agrawal <ankit11.agrawal@nttdata.com>
Implements: blueprint return-request-id-to-caller

subject: WIP: Create a tempest-gabbi zuul job
messages: [{'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-15 16:29:10.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2018-10-19 17:46:15.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned\n\nreplaced by https://review.openstack.org/#/c/611678/'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-15 16:29:10.000000000', 'message': 'WIP: Create a tempest-gabbi zuul job

The job uses the gabbi-tempest plugin to enable the creation of
child jobs that enable easy tempest tests with gabbit files.

This job will eventually live in the gabbi-tempest repo, once
that repo is a part of openstack infra. It is here now to
make progress.

The desired workflow is that a child of the gabbi-tempest job
would set the gabbi_tempest_path var to a directory containing
the gabbi yaml files that are to be tested. The yaml files
would normally be hosted by a project (e.g.,
placement/gate/gabbits).

This is going to take some work to get clean, but the hope
is that this will provide a very simple way for people to
add API tests, based on gabbi, with minimal work required in
tempest itself or tempest plugins. See
https://anticdent.org/gabbi-in-the-gate.html

commit_message:
WIP: Create a tempest-gabbi zuul job

The job uses the gabbi-tempest plugin to enable the creation of
child jobs that enable easy tempest tests with gabbit files.

This job will eventually live in the gabbi-tempest repo, once
that repo is a part of openstack infra. It is here now to
make progress.

The desired workflow is that a child of the gabbi-tempest job
would set the gabbi_tempest_path var to a directory containing
the gabbi yaml files that are to be tested. The yaml files
would normally be hosted by a project (e.g.,
placement/gate/gabbits).

This is going to take some work to get clean, but the hope
is that this will provide a very simple way for people to
add API tests, based on gabbi, with minimal work required in
tempest itself or tempest plugins. See
https://anticdent.org/gabbi-in-the-gate.html

Change-Id: I260d86328ee7a9dbf9b754d1fd7db97f5d35c0ba

Hi Javeme,

OS-INHERIT:inherited_to isn't a valid query parameter in keystone (it may be part of the URL, but not as a query parameters).

Could you please report a bug with what call is breaking in keystone because of the lack of URL encode in the URL query params ?

The point I am asking (as well as Steve and Jamie) is that we don't see a real use for this code (even if it looks fine), nothing is breaking (and isn't expected to) without this patch.

This is why, in order to accept this, a valid bug needs to be reported and referenced in this patch. Thanks"}, {'account_id': 3, 'date': '2016-09-25 17:01:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Verified-1

commit_message:
Encode the url parameters for base.CrudManager

Encode the url query parameters for the method build_key_only_query
of base.CrudManager class.

Many URI include components consisting of or delimited by, certain
special characters.  These characters are called "reserved", since
their usage within the URI component is limited to their reserved
purpose.  If the data for a URI component would conflict with the
reserved purpose, then the conflicting data must be escaped before
forming the URI.
  reserved = ";" | "/" | "?" | ":" | "@" | "&" | "=" | "+" |
             "$" | ","
refs:
  http://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2396.txt
  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/4667942/why-should-i-use-urlencode

Change-Id: I6f6f449b97975dc4867239106c2f3c9622bca9ea

commit_message:
[WIP] Migrate to keystoneauth

Remove all keystoneclient's session and adapter and plugins and rely
completely on keystoneauth.

commit_message:
Allow send null value in extra properties

As CRUD manager for v3 was introduced in commit 315285e,
it was filtering null values from properties. Because of this
it's not possible to unset resource properties. For example,
once project's property was set, it's only possible to change its
value, however, it's not possible to delete that or set it to null.

Change the behavior to allow having nulls in extra properties.

Co-Authored-By: Roman Bogorodskiy <rbogorodskiy@mirantis.com>
Closes-bug: #1560354
Change-Id: I70a9018b39eb973a787fcf94516445be0bacfbad

commit_message:
Drop subnet Port Groups

This patch is dropping the code that creates and handles the
subnet Port Groups. Those were used to place the ACLs that
allowed DHCP traffic to reach the responder in the OVN
pipeline but as explained in the bug description, it's
not needed anymore.

Change-Id: I30bee5c5576554b162e66e1b5dfbe734522ab363
Closes-Bug: #1790900
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit d5a0de261507192b61f2cdf80a537ceaa0792dc3)

commit_message:
Fix the bug about 2 OAUTH API

Currently, 2 API - OAUTH create request token and OAUTH create access
token will return 401 error when the url is admin endpoint because
the url used to create request token and access token is public
endpoint. This fix changes the url to admin endpoint and 2 API can
work normally.

Change-Id: I9b0393c1fb4580caafab75e71eb9c5649ef27fc7
Closes-Bug:#1687593

[{'created': '2018-10-16 19:32:33.000000000', 'message': 'Update sphinx extension logging

Sphinx 1.6 deprecated using the application object to perform logging
and it will be removed in the upcoming 2.0 release. This updates our
extensions to use the recommended sphinx.util.logging instead.

Change-Id: Id7da5a90b804420ece0699e4986b382e6d8bc8f2
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Update sphinx extension logging

Sphinx 1.6 deprecated using the application object to perform logging
and it will be removed in the upcoming 2.0 release. This updates our
extensions to use the recommended sphinx.util.logging instead.

Change-Id: Id7da5a90b804420ece0699e4986b382e6d8bc8f2
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add puppet-horizon-tripleo-standalone job

* It overrrides the tripleo-standalone featureset override to run
  Horizon specific tempest tests and install Horizon tempest plugin.
* It will help to detect the puppet-keystone tempest specific issues
  early in gates.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/609666

Change-Id: I2bb4c62e0926ea147bc8403f1cabdc05e5fc0129

commit_message:
Make Request Logging a little better

Use the flask.request properties instead of direct environ lookups,
as this is more representative of what is happening in the application.

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-11 19:39:17.000000000', 'message': 'Register exceptions with a Flask Error Handler

Exceptions are now handled in the Flask APP instead of in the
legacy webob Application code (at this point that code was living
in the URL Normalizing Middleware). All Keystone API exceptions
(derived from keystone.exception.Error) are automatically
registered on definition with the
keystone.exception.KEYSTONE_API_EXCEPTIONS set. This set is
processed once the app is created in keystone.server.application
to the flask-friendly handler.

TypeError and generic Exception are registered to an explicit
error handler that converts TypeError to ValidationError (BAD_REQUEST)
and all other Exceptions to UnexpectedError (INTERNAL SERVER ERROR).
These exceptions are then emitted in a "jsonify-ed" manner to the
client.

Two other minor changes were required:

* Unenforced API decorator had it's core functionality split into
  a dedicated function that can be called in the case of an error
  being raised in a "before_request" function (such as validation
  in the JSON Body before request func.

* The JSON Body before request func now explicitly sets the
  api to "unenforced_ok" if it is raising an exception. This
  prevents the flask "was this API enforced" assertion from failing
  because @unenforced_api was never run (the ValidationError was
  raised prior to the resource's method being called).

Change-Id: I0d0ef6a774eb86b4769238ed34d7703232ce86c3
Partial-Bug: #1776504
'}, {'created': '2018-10-12 17:34:26.000000000', 'message': 'Register exceptions with a Flask Error Handler

legacy webob Application code (at this point that code was living
in the URL Normalizing Middleware). All Keystone API exceptions
(derived from keystone.exception.Error) are automatically
registered on definition with the
keystone.exception.KEYSTONE_API_EXCEPTIONS set. This set is
processed once the app is created in keystone.server.application
to the flask-friendly handler.

TypeError and generic Exception are registered to an explicit
error handler that converts TypeError to ValidationError (BAD_REQUEST)
and all other Exceptions to UnexpectedError (INTERNAL SERVER ERROR).
These exceptions are then emitted in a "jsonify-ed" manner to the
client.

Two other minor changes were required:

* Unenforced API decorator had it's core functionality split into
  a dedicated function that can be called in the case of an error
  being raised in a "before_request" function (such as validation
  in the JSON Body before request func.

* The JSON Body before request func now explicitly sets the
  api to "unenforced_ok" if it is raising an exception. This
  prevents the flask "was this API enforced" assertion from failing
  because @unenforced_api was never run (the ValidationError was
  raised prior to the resource's method being called).

Change-Id: I0d0ef6a774eb86b4769238ed34d7703232ce86c3
Partial-Bug: #1776504
'}]
commit_message:
Register exceptions with a Flask Error Handler

Exceptions are now handled in the Flask APP instead of in the
legacy webob Application code (at this point that code was living
in the URL Normalizing Middleware). All Keystone API exceptions
(derived from keystone.exception.Error) are automatically
registered on definition with the
keystone.exception.KEYSTONE_API_EXCEPTIONS set. This set is
processed once the app is created in keystone.server.application
to the flask-friendly handler.

TypeError and generic Exception are registered to an explicit
error handler that converts TypeError to ValidationError (BAD_REQUEST)
and all other Exceptions to UnexpectedError (INTERNAL SERVER ERROR).
These exceptions are then emitted in a "jsonify-ed" manner to the
client.

Two other minor changes were required:

* Unenforced API decorator had it's core functionality split into
  a dedicated function that can be called in the case of an error
  being raised in a "before_request" function (such as validation
  in the JSON Body before request func.

* The JSON Body before request func now explicitly sets the
  api to "unenforced_ok" if it is raising an exception. This
  prevents the flask "was this API enforced" assertion from failing
  because @unenforced_api was never run (the ValidationError was
  raised prior to the resource's method being called).

Change-Id: I0d0ef6a774eb86b4769238ed34d7703232ce86c3
Partial-Bug: #1776504

Requirements jobs failed because https://review.openstack.org/#/c/610061/1 wasn't merged."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-15 14:36:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Looking at the Queens release notes, there is one that might be able to be a pre-upgrade check:

https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/keystone/queens.html#upgrade-notes

"The resource backend cannot be configured to anything but SQL if the SQL Identity backend is being used. The resource backend must now be SQL which allows for the use of Foreign Keys to domains/projects wherever desired. This makes managing project relationships and such much more straight forward. The inability to configure non-SQL resource backends has been in Keystone since at least Ocata. This is eliminating some complexity and preventing the need for some really ugly back-port SQL migrations in favor of a better model. Resource is highly relational and should be SQL based."

Adding that in Stein might be kind of weird, but would still be good for people doing fast-forward upgrades from Queens (or earlier) to Stein.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-15 14:38:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-10-15 14:38:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-15 14:42:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-10-15 14:57:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(1 comment)

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > Looking at the Queens release notes, there is one that might be
 > able to be a pre-upgrade check:
 > 
 > https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/keystone/queens.html#upgrade-notes
 > 
 > "The resource backend cannot be configured to anything but SQL if
 > the SQL Identity backend is being used. The resource backend must
 > now be SQL which allows for the use of Foreign Keys to
 > domains/projects wherever desired. This makes managing project
 > relationships and such much more straight forward. The inability to
 > configure non-SQL resource backends has been in Keystone since at
 > least Ocata. This is eliminating some complexity and preventing the
 > need for some really ugly back-port SQL migrations in favor of a
 > better model. Resource is highly relational and should be SQL
 > based."
 > 
 > Adding that in Stein might be kind of weird, but would still be
 > good for people doing fast-forward upgrades from Queens (or
 > earlier) to Stein.

Keystone exposes that as an entry-point though, so someone could roll their own resource backend and configure keystone to use that, which would be a false positive when running keystone-status upgrade check.

Is there a particular way we should handle something like that?'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-10-15 15:31:44.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-10-15 15:32:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5046, 'date': '2018-10-15 15:33:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-16 14:19:35.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6:

> Keystone exposes that as an entry-point though, so someone could roll their own resource backend and configure keystone to use that, which would be a false positive when running keystone-status upgrade check.

In other words you won't know until you load up the extension via stevedore and find out it's not SQL right? If it's something that we won't know about until runtime, then it's probably not good to have in an upgrade check. It's probably possible to load the extension point in a check, but maybe not worth it."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-16 14:20:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2018-10-16 14:28:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

commit_message:
Implement scaffolding for upgrade checks

One of the community goals for Stein is to implement a command-line
tool for operators that runs programmable checks that might impact
upgradability.

This commit lays down the basic structure for the upgrade checks and
ties it up to `keystone-status` command.

Story: 2003657
Task: 26135
Change-Id: I6586827104156ac549217967a1b9171f1a3b32e4

code looks good, just one nit'}, {'account_id': 23567, 'date': '2018-10-05 13:14:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

Seems this is the work to add UDP at ovn-provider: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/608252/, perhaps worth to add depends on. Also, it seems that it will not allow to have listeners of different protocols'}, {'account_id': 21041, 'date': '2018-10-07 06:27:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

> Seems this is the work to add UDP at ovn-provider:
 > https://review.openstack.org/#/c/608252/, perhaps worth to add
 > depends on. Also, it seems that it will not allow to have listeners
 > of different protocols

Although UDP support for ovn is still in progress, with the new code, in case of unsupported listener's protocol or protocols combination (e.g: UDP + TCP in OVN case)is provided, we"ll take care of it (BadRequest exception) and LBaaSV2 driver will return None.

So we should be fine also without setting dependency to the OVN-UDP support patch.

In that case, I would prefer not to set the dependency to the ovn-udp patch, if you still think we should have this dependency, let me know & I"ll add it.

commit_message:
K8S-services: add support for UDP ports

With the support of UDP load balancing in Octavia [1],
Kuryr can handle also K8S-services with UDP ports.
This patch adds support for UDP listener's  protocol in
LBaaS driver, and in addition, handles the case in which
listener's protocol is not supported by Octavia.

Todos:
 * Update the UDP Services tests in kury-tempest
 * 'Howto' doc for UDP services verification

[1] https://developer.openstack.org/api-ref/load-balancer/v2/index.html#create-listener

Change-Id: I93a27af10e531250e07cf6abaa3c060d7090116f
Closes-Bug: 1792768

commit_message:
use include_tasks instead of include

include is marked as deprecated since ansible 2.4[0]

Switch to include_tasks or import_playbook as necessary

[0] https://docs.ansible.com/ansible/2.4/include_module.html#deprecated

Change-Id: I646c3a299981e2b3e155c0316a1abb03a8943c7e
(cherry picked from commit 21cc85a5ead9fbcecb3312c2721f5a8427d8df6f)

commit_message:
Use '/' for the vhost if the transport_url has no trailing '/'

This change https://review.openstack.org/#/c/599912/ accidentally
removed setting the virtual host to '/' if none were provided in the
transport_url configuration option.

Closes-Bug: #1798241
Change-Id: I2dbcec3f77eb7cc513350b00ea020cc8faaecec1

Closes-Bug: #1797815

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-18 09:15:05.000000000', 'message': 'Update OnClauseSPec task name criteria

The OnClauseSpec required Task names to be \w+ or [a-zA-Z0-9_]
which is not enforced by the DSL, so it was possible to have
valid task names that could not be referenced in an on-clause.

YAML enforces some restrictions on characters in task names (#, !, |)
but other than that any JSON-schema valid string should be a valid Task
name

Change-Id: I3f1056cad7c67e160a082c2a0de2e3bfd476bc63
Closes-Bug: 1797439
(cherry picked from commit e98614cd606a863030fb98b23eff099b19ec868d)

but other than that any JSON-schema valid string should be a valid Task

Change-Id: I3f1056cad7c67e160a082c2a0de2e3bfd476bc63

commit_message:
Update OnClauseSPec task name criteria

The OnClauseSpec required Task names to be \w+ or [a-zA-Z0-9_]
which is not enforced by the DSL, so it was possible to have
valid task names that could not be referenced in an on-clause.

YAML enforces some restrictions on characters in task names (#, !, |)
but other than that any JSON-schema valid string should be a valid Task
name

Change-Id: I3f1056cad7c67e160a082c2a0de2e3bfd476bc63
Closes-Bug: 1797439
(cherry picked from commit e98614cd606a863030fb98b23eff099b19ec868d)

commit_message:
Add os_manila role to openstack-ansible

Adding an openstack-ansible role for the manila shared filesystem as a
service project.  This role is meant to deploy, configure and manage
configuration for the manila api, scheduler, share and data services
with the default NFS or other supported backends like cephfs.

Needed-By: I491997a36dfe7e1d2db1347b68d6410cff483633
Change-Id: I79cdb50333d65c575e1ae5e4eaa1005faf140aee

commit_message:
Revert "Reduce gate window floor to 10"

This reverts commit 24221d2c0b84449eb6c5c216918a87dd8e5528e5.

This hasn't had a noticeable impact on the check queue backlog. It is
still floating around 2 ish hours. We may as well go back to larger gate
windows in an attempt to merge more code.

Change-Id: I1b8b90ce371e66cbde63f0f7a62b9aebe0401835

commit_message:
Updated tripleo-puppet-ci-centos-7-standalone job to run tempest tests

* tripleo-puppet-ci-centos-7-standalone is setting up TripleO standalone
  against puppet-openstack-integration project to test all puppet modules
  at once.
* It updates the same job to run only tempest scenario tests.

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/609666

Change-Id: If89417f43a19b42d795f1d6dfc940ad9e1cac145

commit_message:
Remove fetch-tox-output from release-openstack-python

We do not use tox -e venv anymore for release-openstack-python, remove
it to avoid an failure like:
http://logs.openstack.org/33/33d839da8acb93a36a45186d158262f269e9bbd6/release/release-openstack-python/3a9339d/job-output.txt.gz#_2018-10-19_14_13_36_512020

Change-Id: Ib2fd39b0f9b6799e8b5a39044e70b2540b2b5541

subject: Downgrade pip to work around poise-python issue
messages:
[{'account_id': 14790, 'date': '2018-10-19 14:14:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-10-19 15:42:46.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Verified+1 by Zuul (22348)
'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-10-19 15:43:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Verified+2 Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Force-merging to unblock stable gate'}, {'account_id': 13252, 'date': '2018-10-19 15:43:06.000000000', 'content': 'Change has been successfully merged by Jens Harbott (frickler)'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-19 14:14:30.000000000', 'message': "Downgrade pip to work around poise-python issue

There is a bug in the poise-python cookbook because it depends on
internal features of pip and these internals have changed in pip 18.1,
see [0]. We have a workaround in the openstack-common cookbook proposed,
but that doesn't work if the server has pip 18.1 pre-installed, as seems
to be the case for the infra-provided CI image. So as a further

commit_message:
Downgrade pip to work around poise-python issue

There is a bug in the poise-python cookbook because it depends on
internal features of pip and these internals have changed in pip 18.1,
see [0]. We have a workaround in the openstack-common cookbook proposed,
but that doesn't work if the server has pip 18.1 pre-installed, as seems
to be the case for the infra-provided CI image. So as a further
workaround we need to downgrade the pre-installed pip version for the
time being.

[0] https://github.com/poise/poise-python/issues/133

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/610427
Change-Id: I52514691d3f271579628b62539222f7307957ba0
(cherry picked from commit 973119bad3fa163a1c3ad2b4190740818fc7d44f)

commit_message:
Downgrade pip to work around poise-python issue

There is a bug in the poise-python cookbook because it depends on
internal features of pip and these internals have changed in pip 18.1,
see [0]. We have a workaround in the openstack-common cookbook proposed,
but that doesn't work if the server has pip 18.1 pre-installed, as seems
to be the case for the infra-provided CI image. So as a further
workaround we need to downgrade the pre-installed pip version for the
time being.

[0] https://github.com/poise/poise-python/issues/133

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/610427
Change-Id: I52514691d3f271579628b62539222f7307957ba0
(cherry picked from commit 973119bad3fa163a1c3ad2b4190740818fc7d44f)

commit_message:
Check GPT table with sgdisk insread of partprobe

On centos7.2, it doesn't happen every time, but sometimes, partprobe
fails with error `Device or resource busy` in _fix_gpt_structs. In fact,
this is not a problem, I tried ignoring this error and ran remain code.
Things went well. The target of running `partprobe` is to check GPT
table, we can run `sgdisk -v` instead.

This patch is to replace `partprobe` command in _fix_gpt_structs to
avoid `Device or resource busy` error.

Change-Id: I43182f17b1c6229132814313f7582ab30245f6bb
(cherry picked from commit b9a109c65f23b217aac9e698fdfd47f4fc174331)

commit_message:
migration: Do some pre-flight checks before migration

This patch checks the availability of the external networks
and floating ips before generating inventory (so the admin
is alerted as soon as possible) and before starting migration
to make sure that still there are enough floating ips available.

This patch also removes the DVR flag, as the ansible scripts
are independent of the DVR configuration on the system.

Change-Id: Ifca00065ce2457437794e34fd6700394db2c3dc5

commit_message:
Infrared plugin: Fix the permission issue with the start-ovn-migration script

The mode param of the ansible module 'template' was not indented properly.
This patch fixes it.

Change-Id: Iea86c4fa2d7e00c45eb36db04b7769a7b0dbf435

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-18 13:50:40.000000000', 'message': 'tasks: neutron_install: Fix apparmor delegation to physical hosts.

Previously, we only executed the AppArmor configuration when the
inventory_hostname matched one of the hosts in the neutron_appamor_hosts
list. However, there are cases were a multiple LXC hosts share the same
physical host. In that case, since we only record one container per
physical host, that container may not be part of the running inventory,
so the AppArmor configuration is never executed. We fix that by simply
recording all the physical hosts and then include the file if the host
is located on one of the recorded physical hosts.

Change-Id: Ib523de857a5de9adc86bd90fe6919af17704192f
'}, {'created': '2018-10-18 15:59:23.000000000', 'message': 'tasks: neutron_install: Fix group for neutron hosts

Previously, we only executed the AppArmor configuration when the
inventory_hostname matched one of the hosts in the neutron_appamor_hosts
list. However, there are cases were a multiple LXC hosts share the same
physical host. In that case, since we only record one container per
physical host, that container may not be part of the running inventory,
so the AppArmor configuration is never executed. We fix that by simply
iterating the neutron_all group which should contain all the hosts which
participate in the neutron deployment.

Change-Id: Ib523de857a5de9adc86bd90fe6919af17704192f
'}, {'created': '2018-10-19 07:36:04.000000000', 'message': 'tasks: neutron_install: Fix group for neutron hosts

Previously, we only executed the AppArmor configuration when the
inventory_hostname matched one of the hosts in the neutron_appamor_hosts
list. However, there are cases were a multiple LXC hosts share the same
physical host. In that case, since we only record one container per
physical host, that container may not be part of the running inventory,
so the AppArmor configuration is never executed. We fix that by simply
iterating the neutron_all group which should contain all the hosts which
participate in the neutron deployment.

Change-Id: Ib523de857a5de9adc86bd90fe6919af17704192f
'}]
commit_message:
tasks: neutron_install: Fix group for neutron hosts

Previously, we only executed the AppArmor configuration when the
inventory_hostname matched one of the hosts in the neutron_appamor_hosts
list. However, there are cases were a multiple LXC hosts share the same
physical host. In that case, since we only record one container per
physical host, that container may not be part of the running inventory,
so the AppArmor configuration is never executed. We fix that by simply
iterating the neutron_all group which should contain all the hosts which
participate in the neutron deployment.

Change-Id: Ib523de857a5de9adc86bd90fe6919af17704192f

commit_message:
Remove dependency to OSH repository of new jobs

Without this patch, there is a dependency between the two
repositories OSH and OSH-infra, which was recently introduced, and
which will cause a circular dependency problem when trying to remove
the duplicated jobs that will appear in OSH.

Change-Id: Ief4461a66f7139ae0650e4a240a3e65800821f78
Required-By: https://review.openstack.org/610481/
Co-Authored-By: Jean-Philippe Evrard <jean-philippe@evrard.me>

commit_message:
releasenotes: oslo-messaging-separate-backends add project name

Without this patch, the release notes published at
https://docs.openstack.org/releasenotes/openstack-ansible/rocky.html contains
the same line multiple times which is not very clear.

[...]
    Support separate oslo.messaging services for RPC and Notifications
    to enable operation of separate and different messaging backend servers.

    Support separate oslo.messaging services for RPC and Notifications
    to enable operation of separate and different messaging backend servers.
[...]

Change-Id: I0ed1a43670d97f2e2215d04c641f7bd4cfbe4f44
(cherry picked from commit 5e11ba0377f87bd0c38a127317de523df1b7be1a)

commit_message:
Fix a LOG.warning which didn't work properly

Found when checking ci logs here:

http://logs.openstack.org/41/587041/3/check/ironic-inspector-tempest-dsvm-discovery/7912a3a/logs/screen-ironic-inspector.txt.gz#_Oct_17_16_44_39_477744

It's supposed to be printing missing arguments when constructing
an http client.

The http client is supposed to be removed ?soon?, so if the fix is
not required, please let me know.

Change-Id: I2bad387afa2ede56da7164a7bc9a5ac461e78d9c

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-29 23:50:06.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: If134cb43df5b974c1cbd2415b144f6805d37893a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}]
commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: If134cb43df5b974c1cbd2415b144f6805d37893a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-16 19:53:20.000000000', 'message': 'Update sphinx extension logging

Sphinx 1.6 deprecated using the application object to perform logging
and it will be removed in the upcoming 2.0 release. This updates our
extensions to use the recommended sphinx.util.logging instead.

Change-Id: I49f55758b65e358154f3afbff3c47d1857073a4a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>
'}]
commit_message:
Update sphinx extension logging

Sphinx 1.6 deprecated using the application object to perform logging
and it will be removed in the upcoming 2.0 release. This updates our
extensions to use the recommended sphinx.util.logging instead.

Change-Id: I49f55758b65e358154f3afbff3c47d1857073a4a
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

There is a bug in the poise-python cookbook because it depends on
internal features of pip and these internals have changed in pip 18.1,
see [0]. We have a workaround in the openstack-common cookbook proposed,
but that doesn't work if the server has pip 18.1 pre-installed, as seems
to be the case for the infra-provided CI image. So as a further
workaround we need to downgrade the pre-installed pip version for the
time being.

[0] https://github.com/poise/poise-python/issues/133

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/610427
Change-Id: I52514691d3f271579628b62539222f7307957ba0
"}]
commit_message:
Downgrade pip to work around poise-python issue

There is a bug in the poise-python cookbook because it depends on
internal features of pip and these internals have changed in pip 18.1,
see [0]. We have a workaround in the openstack-common cookbook proposed,
but that doesn't work if the server has pip 18.1 pre-installed, as seems
to be the case for the infra-provided CI image. So as a further
workaround we need to downgrade the pre-installed pip version for the
time being.

[0] https://github.com/poise/poise-python/issues/133

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/610427
Change-Id: I52514691d3f271579628b62539222f7307957ba0

revisions:
[{'created': '2018-09-29 23:54:19.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ib45159432550c6c15a29443d8c786e8f28c1d0c4
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
'}, {'created': '2018-10-10 08:00:10.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

Change-Id: Ib45159432550c6c15a29443d8c786e8f28c1d0c4

Co-Authored-By: Bartosz Zurkowski <b.zurkowski@samsung.com>

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ib45159432550c6c15a29443d8c786e8f28c1d0c4
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
Co-Authored-By: Bartosz Zurkowski <b.zurkowski@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Correct updating baremetal nodes by name or ID

Currently any resource created via Resource.new is marked as clean from
the point of view of JSON patch. This is not correct and prevents node
updates from working when the first argument is an ID.

Conflicts:
	openstack/tests/unit/image/v2/test_image.py

Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/610753
Change-Id: I850cb6defb71c62121eafbf853473013e2780e2b
(cherry picked from commit 0962342cf29f4aa431fe6889524d33844f0c2d68)

subject: DNM: Logging public server code path
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-19 13:29:33.000000000', 'message': "DNM: Logging public server code path

This patch adds a logger 'test_sdk' that allows us to discover what
code path is being executed when creating a public server on an
arbitrary cloud, i.e. whether its public IP is assigned via DHCP
directly or via NAT mechanism.

Change-Id: I586469dca5408aec7221f303950b6d6a971b91c8
"}]
commit_message:
DNM: Logging public server code path

This patch adds a logger 'test_sdk' that allows us to discover what
code path is being executed when creating a public server on an
arbitrary cloud, i.e. whether its public IP is assigned via DHCP
directly or via NAT mechanism.

Change-Id: I586469dca5408aec7221f303950b6d6a971b91c8

subject: DNM: Logging image code path
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-10-19 13:25:17.000000000', 'message': "DNM: Logging image code path

This patch adds a logger 'test_sdk' that allows us to discover what
code path is being executed when creating an image on an arbitrary
cloud, i.e. whether it is uploaded via PUT on the Glance service or
as an object to Swift and then imported to Glance via Task API.

Change-Id: I16bf071ee6e46ce8644a57b05c3b91da285b353c
"}]
commit_message:
DNM: Logging image code path

This patch adds a logger 'test_sdk' that allows us to discover what
code path is being executed when creating an image on an arbitrary
cloud, i.e. whether it is uploaded via PUT on the Glance service or
as an object to Swift and then imported to Glance via Task API.

Change-Id: I16bf071ee6e46ce8644a57b05c3b91da285b353c

subject: Allow to batch data flush on disk in SSYNC
messages:
[{'account_id': 13852, 'date': '2018-10-12 09:57:21.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13852, 'date': '2018-10-12 10:02:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Workflow-1

This gives us a 3x perf improvement on updates() function during revert'}, {'account_id': 13852, 'date': '2018-10-12 11:55:26.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 13852, 'date': '2018-10-12 11:56:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Workflow-1'}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-10-12 17:59:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)

Interesting... we'll want some tests that use the new mode, of course. And I'll have to think a bit about what this means for our notion of object atomicity -- my understanding was that we do all these fsyncs to ensure that for a given path that the object-server might open, either the data and all its metadata are there, or nothing is.

If we write a bunch of things to the filesystem then hit an error (or even restart) before the sync() call, can we find ourselves in a situation where we have data but no metadata? Or metadata but no data? Or the file gets linked, but not all of the data got written? If we get into a bad situation like this, how will the object-server respond? Presumably the auditor will quarantine/clean it up eventually... What happens if the replicator/reconstructor gets there first, though? Can we get ourselves into a situation where the replicator keeps pushing around malformed objects faster than the auditor can get them quarantined?"}, {'account_id': 15343, 'date': '2018-10-12 21:51:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 13852, 'date': '2018-10-17 07:37:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> And I'll have to think a bit about what this means for our
 > notion of object atomicity -- my understanding was that we do all
 > these fsyncs to ensure that for a given path that the object-server
 > might open, either the data and all its metadata are there, or
 > nothing is.
 > 
 > If we write a bunch of things to the filesystem then hit an error
 > (or even restart) before the sync() call, can we find ourselves in
 > a situation where we have data but no metadata? Or metadata but no
 > data? Or the file gets linked, but not all of the data got written?

To be sure, I asked on the linux-xfs mailing-list. You can find the whole discussion at [1], but the answer that will interest you is the one from Dave Chinner. He says that it behaves the same. All data will get written before an inode is inserted. The point about performance is because he does not know we are working on a lot of files at once. Of course, this sync() optimisation is mainly useful when working on lots of small files, because with few big files, there is not much fsync().

[1] https://lwn.net/ml/linux-xfs/6A65F394-C1BA-4339-AC9B-051885D12F65@corp.ovh.com/"}, {'account_id': 13852, 'date': '2018-10-19 12:46:04.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

I followed on the discussion on linux-xfs ML. You were right, Dave Chinner completed the answer, it's not safe to do it this way. I'll try an other way (similar to PUT+POST maybe?)"}]

commit_message:
change tox envlist from 3.5 to 3

base python version is 3, not 3.5 and
python 3.5 is not installed in some current
distros so running 'tox' locally fails.

Change-Id: Ie2449a433e07f4cafb55fe1db247ba9f854cef97
(cherry picked from commit e62f1f4f9c6077640b8b016057f780cd02bf040a)

messages:
[{'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2018-05-04 15:42:40.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 18851, 'date': '2018-05-05 22:58:07.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I tested the patch and it doesn't fix the issue."}, {'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2018-05-06 19:49:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Doesn't fix meaning the /etc/os-net-config/config.jaml is empty or you still hit network issue?"}, {'account_id': 18851, 'date': '2018-05-06 22:15:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Doesn't fix meaning the /etc/os-net-config/config.jaml is empty or
 > you still hit network issue?

After applying the fix, during ceph upgrade config.json gets emptied and network connectivity is lost on the internal_api network."}, {'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2018-05-07 11:07:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This sounds strange, during ceph upgrade you should be just reruning deployment steps that already ran during overcloud upgrade on ceph nodes. We should step this a bit deeper, we have /etc/.../config.json which is generated by the /usr/libexec.. which is called by os-apply-config. So during ffwd prepare it gets new format fails on it and generates empty file which shouldnt matter as we should remove the libexec in ffwd run and reinitiate the config.json during upgrade. If network is lost during ceps upgrade we must have something else wrong and we are just masking the issue by removal of libexec?'}, {'account_id': 11166, 'date': '2018-10-19 12:41:49.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: Ibe122955cbec8421848ff6a8ad9725800b771c2d
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

- replace CEPH_RGW_KEYSTONE_API_VERSION with
  CEPH_RGW_IDENTITY_API_VERSION everywhere
  (the latter is the actual var defined at the start of the file)

- replace "http://$SERVICE_HOST:35357" with $KEYSTONE_IDENTITY_URI
  (in DevStack keystone is deployed under apache w/o ports in URI,
  with admin endpoint the same as public one)

Change-Id: I981935982b7fab3bb8d3fe9047de7cae3c35d2a0
'}]
commit_message:
Fix RGW Keystone vars

- replace CEPH_RGW_KEYSTONE_API_VERSION with
  CEPH_RGW_IDENTITY_API_VERSION everywhere
  (the latter is the actual var defined at the start of the file)

- replace "http://$SERVICE_HOST:35357" with $KEYSTONE_IDENTITY_URI
  (in DevStack keystone is deployed under apache w/o ports in URI,
  with admin endpoint the same as public one)

Change-Id: I981935982b7fab3bb8d3fe9047de7cae3c35d2a0

commit_message:
Honor blacklist during temp key injection

The server blacklist also needs to be honored when getting the list
of hosts that we use to check for the ssh port being available, and
injecting the temporary ssh key.

Change-Id: I7ea9201f39af17bb43b7a1b8a9d8d1064e365c14
Closes-Bug: #1797572

commit_message:
Add tht to mistral_executor (for plan create)

This patch adds the openstack-tripleo-heat-templates package
to the mistral_executor container. This resolves issues in
importing the default plan when using containers for the
Undercloud.

Change-Id: I96c2fc6750874b20274410fd6f19db6275075f11
Closes-bug: #1756545

commit_message:
Add workaround to pin pip to 18.0

The default recipe does not work with the latest version of pip. The
workaround is to override to 18.0

Change-Id: If245c3c51930beba151ed8a42cec15131ea28098

commit_message:
Update fetcher options

This updates the options registered in fetcher/__init__.py

Following modifications have been done:

* Add "fetcher" to common/config.py for config file generation

* Update "fetcher/backend" option help

* Rename "fetchers_opts" to "fetcher_opts": Only one fetcher per processor is
  used. This aims at clarifying the code

Change-Id: I408d4ea7b8009e90e93c8dc72635c8d362c4598a

commit_message:
[swarm-mode] Remove --live-restore from Docker daemon options

Ensure the --live-restore is not in the Docker daemon OPTIONS.

Some images has this option by default which will cause the node
not being able to perform it swarm init process.

Change-Id: I287a5274143903fad5d4476e9d1640b26bdb46d4
Story: 2004095
Task: 27497

revisions:
[{'created': '2016-11-07 12:16:22.000000000', 'message': 'Implement Driver API for dynamic iPXE config

This patch adds two new abstract mixin classes, DeployIPXEMixin and
BootIPXEMixin, which define methods to fetch options needed for
dynamic iPXE configuration from deploy and boot interfaces respectively.

Implementations are added to AgentDeployMixin and PXEBoot interfaces,
so that both Agent and ISCSI deploy can be used with dynamic
iPXE configuration.

New config option `[pxe]ipxe_server_enabled` is added which enables
some discrimination for when do or do not create pxe configs on disk and
which PXE DHCP options to set.
Later it will be used on REST API side as well.

This option is set to deprecated right away, as it sole purpose is to
give operatos that use custom out-of-tree iPXE boot scripts and configs
time to update those to proper Jinja templates.
After deprecation period it should be merged into `[pxe]ipxe_enabled`
option to use dynamic iPXE configuration by default in iPXE environments.

The sample of ironic.conf file is not updated on purpose to not confuse
users, as this option is not yet to be enabled until API-side changes
are implemented.

Change-Id: I259f356fc046f89e28f7ca4ef7301113b3c752ef
Partial-Bug: #1526275
'}, {'created': '2016-11-07 13:56:27.000000000', 'message': 'Implement Driver API for dynamic iPXE config

'}, {'created': '2016-11-28 19:18:57.000000000', 'message': 'Implement Driver API for dynamic boot config

This patch adds two new methods to base deploy and boot interfaces -
`get_boot_config_options` (by default returns an empty dict) and
`get_boot_config` (by default raises NotImplementedError exception)
respectively.
These will be used for dynamic boot config generation.

Implementations are added to AgentDeployMixin and PXEBoot interfaces,
so that both Agent and ISCSI deploy can be used with dynamic
iPXE configuration.

New config option `[pxe]ipxe_server_enabled` is added which enables
some discrimination for when do or do not create pxe configs on disk and
which PXE DHCP options to set.
Later it will be used on ironic-api side as well.

This option is set to deprecated right away, as it sole purpose is to
give operatos that use custom out-of-tree iPXE boot scripts and configs
time to update those to proper Jinja templates.
After deprecation period it should be merged into `[pxe]ipxe_enabled`
option to use dynamic iPXE configuration by default in iPXE environments.

The sample of ironic.conf file is not updated on purpose to not confuse
users, as this option is not yet to be enabled until API-side changes
are implemented.

Change-Id: I259f356fc046f89e28f7ca4ef7301113b3c752ef
Partial-Bug: #1526275
